publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: A Man with Expence & Wonderfull Toyle
By planting & dunging enobled his Soyle
There fruits of ye best ye Taste did Invite
And uniform Orders still courted ye Sight
Noe degenerate Weed, ye Ground did produce
But all things afforded both beauty & Use
Till from Dunghill transplanted while yet but a Seed
A nettle reared up his Inglorious head
The Gardiner wou'd Wisely, have rooted him up
To Stop ye Increase of a barbarous Crop
But ye Master forbad him, & after ye fashion
Of foolish good Nature & blind Moderation
Forbore him thro' pity & chose as much rather
to Ask him Some questions, first how came thither
Kind Sr Quoth ye Nettle a Stranger I come
for Conscience compelled to relinquish my home
Cause I woud not Subscribe to a Mystery Dark
That ye Prince of all Trees was ye Iesuits Bark
An Erroneous Tenett, I Know Sr that You
No more then my Self will allow to be true
To you I for Refuge & Sanctuary Sue
There's none So renowned for Compassion as you
And tho' in Some things I may differ from these
The rest of ye fruitfull & Beautifull Trees
Tho' your Digging & Dunging my Nature much harms
And I cannot Comply with ye Gardiners Forms
Yett I & my Family after our Fashion
Will peacably Stick to our own Education
Be pleased to allow us a place for to rest
And wee none of yr Family ere will molest
a Kind Shelter to us & Protection afford
wee'll doe you no harm I'll give you my word
The Good man was Soon won wth this plausible Tale
(So fraud on good Nature does often prevaile)
He Welcomes his Guest gives him full Toleration
in ye midst of ye Garden to take up his Station
And into his Bosom does his Ennemy Bring
He never Suspected ye Nettle wou'd Sting
till Flushed wth Success, of Strength to be feared
Around him a Numerous offspring he reared
Then ye Master grew Sensible of wt he had done
And fain wou'd have had his new Guest to be gone
But now t'was to late to bid him turn out
A well rooted possession already was gott
The Old Trees decayd, & in their room grew
a Stubborn, rank, Pestilent, poisonous Crew
The Master who first ye young Brood had admitted
They stung like Ingrates & left him unpittied
No Help from Manuring or planting was found
The weeds had eat out ye Heart of ye Ground
Thus one Nettle uncroped encreased to Such Store
That t'was nothing but Weeds, wt was Garden beforeX85-743O
